SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to three-digit dividends and one-digit divisors with place value understanding using rectangular arrays, area models, repeated subtraction, partial quotients, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division.
Content: There are 594 children participating in a county science fair. They are put into groups of six children. How many groups will participate?

SubTopics: Classify quadrilaterals and triangles based on angle measure, side lengths, and the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines.
Content: Which figure has AT LEAST one acute angle, one obtuse angle, and one right angle?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication.
Content: Each day of the work week, Mr. Harbin uses 3/4 of a gallon of gas. Which estimate BEST describes the amount of gas Mr. Harbin would use in a five-day work week?

SubTopics: Understand and justify decompositions of fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.
Content: The body and head of a fox measure 19 4/5 inches, and its tail measures 10 4/5 inches. What is the total length of the fox?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to three-digit dividends and one-digit divisors with place value understanding using rectangular arrays, area models, repeated subtraction, partial quotients, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division.
Content: There are 136 students in the school cafeteria. There are 8 students sitting at each table. How many tables are in the cafeteria?

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for whole numbers up to and including 50.
Content: Which list contains EXACTLY 2 prime numbers and 2 composite numbers?

SubTopics: Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers up to and including 100,000 using the standard algorithm with place value understanding.
Content: A cafeteria manager ordered 1,251 cartons of milk on Monday.

:ibox:• He also ordered cartons of milk on Thursday.
• He ordered 879 more cartons on Monday than on Thursday.
How many cartons did the manager order on Thursday?

SubTopics: Use decimal notation to represent fractions.
Content: Dana ran on Monday and Tuesday.

:ibox:• She ran 5 2/10 km on Monday.
• She ran 4 6/100 km on Tuesday.
How far did Dana run altogether?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction is equivalent to another fraction by using area and length fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size.
Content: What fraction is shaded in each of these models?
problems/NC18G4M/media/9a.jpg
problems/NC18G4M/media/9b.jpg

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, using the denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions.
Content: A group of friends were each completing a project of the same size. This table shows how much of the project each friend has completed.
problems/NC18G4M/media/10a.jpg
Which friends have completed an EQUAL amount of their project?

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to three digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply up to two two-digit numbers with place value understanding using area models, partial products, and the properties of operations. Use models to make connections and develop the algorithm.
Content: Pablo was getting ready for a bike race.

:ibox:• He rode his bike each day for 32 days.
• He rode his bike for 45 minutes each day.
How many minutes did Pablo spend riding his bike to get ready for the race?

SubTopics: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison. Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparisons using models and equations with a symbol for the unknown number. Distinguish multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Content: There are twice as many women on a bus as there are men. There are 24 women on the bus. What is the total number of men and women on the bus?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction is equivalent to another fraction by using area and length fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size.
Content: Patrick’s sister will eat 4 of the cookies. What fraction of the cookies will be left?
problems/NC18G4M/media/13a.jpg
Patrick’s sister will eat 4 of the cookies. What fraction of the cookies will be left?

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to three digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply up to two two-digit numbers with place value understanding using area models, partial products, and the properties of operations. Use models to make connections and develop the algorithm.
Content: Each classroom at a school has 24 desks. There are 18 classrooms in the school. How many desks are at the school?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication.
Content: Four friends each ate 2/3 of an apple. How many apples did the four friends eat in

SubTopics: olve two-step word problems involving the four operations with whole numbers.
Content: A farmer has an equal number of cows in 3 different fields on his farm. Which choice could be the total number of cows?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to three-digit dividends and one-digit divisors with place value understanding using rectangular arrays, area models, repeated subtraction, partial quotients, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division.
Content: There are 128 pencils to be put into boxes. Each box can hold 9 pencils. How many boxes can be completely filled?

SubTopics: Explain why a fraction is equivalent to another fraction by using area and length fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size.
Content: Which two of these squares have the same amount shaded?

SubTopics: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to three-digit dividends and one-digit divisors with place value understanding using rectangular arrays, area models, repeated subtraction, partial quotients, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division.
Content: A farmer has 348 apples and wants to put them into baskets. He will put 6 apples into each basket. How many baskets will the farmer use?

SubTopics: Understand and justify decompositions of fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.
Content: Maria is making a snack mix. For the recipe, she needs:

:ibox:• 2/4 cup peanuts
• 1/4 cup raisins
• 2/4 cup chocolate chips
Maria will double the recipe. What is the total amount of peanuts, raisins, and chocolate chips she will need?

SubTopics: Develop an understanding of angles and angle measurement.
Content: RVU is a straight line and ∠TVU has a measure of 40° in this figure.
problems/NC18G4M/media/21a.jpg
What is the measure of ∠SVT?

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to three digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply up to two two-digit numbers with place value understanding using area models, partial products, and the properties of operations. Use models to make connections and develop the algorithm.
Content: Michael is solving 23 × 42 using this rectangular array.
problems/NC18G4M/media/22a.jpg
What is the missing number Michael needs to solve this problem?

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for whole numbers up to and including 50.
Content: Which group of numbers includes ONLY composite numbers?

SubTopics: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers up to and including 100,000 using numerals, number names, and expanded form.
Content: Which choice is equal to 462?

SubTopics: Understand and justify decompositions of fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.
Content: A tree was 14 3/8 inches tall when it was first planted. Two years later, the tree was 21 1/8 inches tall. How much did the tree grow in the two years?

SubTopics: Know relative sizes of measurement units. Solve problems involving metric measurement.
Content: Wendy filled a bucket with vegetables from her garden. The vegetables weighed 7,000 grams. She sold 4,200 grams of the vegetables. How much did the remaining vegetables weigh?

SubTopics: Represent and interpret data using whole numbers.
Content: Fourth-grade students were surveyed about their favorite pizza topping. This graph shows the results.
problems/NC18G4M/media/27a.jpg
How many more fourth-graders chose pepperoni or sausage than chose the other toppings?

SubTopics: olve two-step word problems involving the four operations with whole numbers.
Content: Last week, Jeff read 8 pages of his book. This week, he has read 6 times as many pages as last week. How many pages has Jeff read altogether during the two weeks?

SubTopics: Classify quadrilaterals and triangles based on angle measure, side lengths, and the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines.
Content: Which polygon can have four sides of equal length, two pairs of parallel sides, and no right angles?

SubTopics: Use multiplicative reasoning to convert metric measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit using place value understanding, two-column tables, and length models.
Content: Maria drank 3 liters of water last week. Her friend drank twice as much water as Maria. How many milliliters of water did they both drink?

SubTopics: Develop an understanding of angles and angle measurement.
Content: Rays PQ and PR are perpendicular.
problems/NC18G4M/media/31a.jpg
What is the value of x?

SubTopics: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size using area and length models, and recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole.
Content: Thomas lives more than 0.55 km and less than 0.75 km from his school. Which choice could be the distance Thomas lives from his school?

SubTopics: Recognize symmetry in a two-dimensional figure, and identify and draw lines of symmetry.
Content: Which figure has the most lines of symmetry?

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for whole numbers up to and including 50.
Content: If this pattern continues, what will the next 3 numbers be?

SubTopics: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals that cross the hour.
Content: Every Saturday morning, Jack reads for 30 minutes, plays basketball for 60 minutes, and rides his bike. If Jack starts these activities at 10:25 a.m. and finishes them at 12:10 p.m., how long does he spend riding his bike?

SubTopics: Understand and justify decompositions of fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.
Content: Which number sentence could be used to solve this problem?

SubTopics: Solve problems with area and perimeter.
Content: Kathy has a garden that is 15 feet wide and 20 feet long. She will plant 1 bulb per square foot. Each bag of bulbs contains 9 bulbs. How many bags does Kathy need to buy?

SubTopics: Compare two multi-digit numbers up to and including 100,000 based on the values of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Content: This table shows the number of students at a school in the years 2014–2016.
problems/NC18G4M/media/38a.jpg
In 2015, there were more students than in 2014 but fewer than in 2016. Which could be the number of students in 2015?

SubTopics: Use decimal notation to represent fractions.
Content: Marcy saw this number line in class.
problems/NC18G4M/media/39a.jpg
Which shaded section has the same value as n?

SubTopics: Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers up to and including 100,000 using the standard algorithm with place value understanding.
Content: There are 1,829 students at a middle school.

:ibox:• 568 students are in 6th grade.
• 629 students are in 7th grade.
• The rest of the students are in 8th grade.
How many students are in 8th grade?
